description: From Middle English agrement, agreement, from Old French agrement, agreement. Morphologically agree +‎ -ment.

entries.meaning: (countable) An understanding between entities to follow a specific course of conduct.
(uncountable) A state whereby several parties share a view or opinion; the state of not contradicting one another.
examples: The results of my experiment are in agreement with those of Michelson and with the law of General Relativity.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, law) A legally binding contract enforceable in a court of law.
(uncountable, linguistics, grammar) Rules that exist in many languages that force some parts of a sentence to be used or inflected differently depending on certain attributes of other parts.
examples: Having clarified what we mean by ‘Personʼ and ‘Numberʼ, we can now return to our earlier observation that a finite I is inflected not only for Tense, but also for Agreement. More particularly, I inflects for Person and Number, and must ‘agreeʼ with its Subject, in the sense that the Person/Number features of I must match those of the Subject.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, chiefly in the plural) An agreeable quality.
examples: Her nymph-like features such agreements have / That I could venture with her to the grave [...].
